GameDBLocalizedString.Text: Tooth Defect Detected on Probing
Instrumental or radiographic examination reveals demineralization or a substantive cavity in the hard tissues of the tooth.
Radiograph Shows Impacted Wisdom Tooth
X-ray or CT imaging shows that the third molar has failed to erupt normally, exhibiting an abnormal position, angle, or obstruction by bone or soft tissue.
Pericoronal Flap Redness, Swelling, and Pus Discharge
The gingival flap covering a partially erupted tooth shows significant redness, swelling, heat, and pain, with pus expressed upon pressure.
Diffuse, Indurated Swelling of Face and Neck
Rapidly spreading swelling with indistinct borders on the face or neck, feeling hard as a board to the touch, accompanied by severe pain.
Radiograph Shows Jaw Bone Destruction
X-ray or CT imaging shows irregular low-density areas, moth-eaten changes, or sequestrum formation in the jawbone.
Painful Salivary Gland Swelling During Meals
The patient experiences recurrent, painful swelling of the submandibular or parotid salivary glands upon eating or seeing food.
Bluish Cyst on Lower Lip
A smooth-surfaced, fluctuant, bluish, translucent cystic mass appears on the lower lip mucosa.
Bluish Cyst on Floor of Mouth
A large, fluctuant, bluish cystic mass, resembling a frog's belly, appears on one side of the lingual frenulum on the floor of the mouth.
Periapical Radiolucency on Non-vital Tooth
Radiographic examination reveals a well-defined, round or oval low-density area in the bone at the apex of a tooth with a necrotic pulp.
Pericoronal Radiolucency around Unerupted Tooth
Radiographic examination shows that the crown of an unerupted tooth is completely surrounded by a well-defined, cystic low-density area.
Mandibular Prognathism with Anterior Crossbite and Concave Profile
The patient's mandible protrudes significantly, causing the lower anterior teeth to bite in front of the upper ones (anterior crossbite), with a "moon face" or concave profile in lateral view.
Maxillary Prognathism with Convex Profile
The patient's maxilla protrudes significantly, causing the upper anterior teeth to flare out (buck teeth), with a convex profile in lateral view.
Micrognathia with Receding Chin
The patient's mandible is underdeveloped, appearing as a short and significantly receded chin.
Facial Asymmetry with Chin Deviation
When viewed from the front, the patient's facial contours are asymmetrical, and the midpoint of the chin is noticeably deviated to one side.
Joint Pain with Clicking and Abnormal Opening
The patient presents with pain in the temporomandibular joint area, joint sounds (such as clicking or crepitus) during mandibular movement, and abnormal opening or closing.
Inability to Close Mouth After Opening Wide
After opening the mouth wide (e.g., yawning), the patient's jaw gets stuck in the open position and cannot be closed voluntarily.
Electric Shock-like Facial Pain
Brief, recurrent, severe pain like an electric shock or knife cut on one side of the face, which can be triggered by light touch or other actions.
Cheilitis with Dryness and Scaling
The lips are red and swollen, accompanied by significant dryness, peeling, cracking, and crusting.
Glossitis with Smooth Tongue
Inflammation of the tongue, with atrophy and disappearance of the lingual papillae on the dorsum, resulting in an abnormally smooth tongue surface that may be red or pale.
Periodontal Attachment Loss and Bone Resorption
Clinical or radiographic examination confirms destruction of the periodontal tissues connecting the tooth and alveolar bone, accompanied by resorption of the alveolar bone.
Gingivitis without Attachment Loss
The gingiva shows signs of inflammation such as redness, swelling, and easy bleeding, but the deeper periodontal supporting tissues (like alveolar bone) are not yet destroyed.
Recurrent Painful Oral Ulcers
The oral mucosa repeatedly develops well-defined, centrally depressed, painful ulcers with a characteristic of periodic recurrence.
Dry Mouth and Eyes with Positive Antibodies
The patient experiences persistent dry mouth and dry eyes, and blood tests reveal autoantibodies associated with Sjögren's syndrome (e.g., SSA/SSB).
Enlarged Tongue with Scalloped Borders
The tongue is abnormally enlarged, causing its edges to be pressed against the teeth, forming distinct wavy indentations (scalloping).
Restricted Tongue Movement due to Short Frenulum
The lingual frenulum connecting the underside of the tongue to the floor of the mouth is too short or tight, preventing normal protrusion or elevation of the tongue.
Progressive Hemifacial Atrophy
The soft and hard tissues of one side of the face progressively atrophy and thin over time, leading to severe facial asymmetry.
Histopathology Shows Keratinized Cyst Wall
Histopathological examination of a cystic lesion within the jawbone reveals its wall is lined with characteristic keratinized epithelium.
Histopathology Shows Ghost Cells in Cyst
Histopathological examination of a cystic lesion within the jawbone reveals the presence of characteristic "ghost cells" and calcifications.
Histopathology Shows Glandular Structures in Cyst
Histopathological examination of a cystic lesion within the jawbone reveals mucus cells and duct-like structures within its epithelium.
Cystic Radiolucency in Place of Missing Tooth
Radiographic examination shows a cystic low-density area in the bone at the location of a congenitally missing tooth.
Cyst Lateral to Vital Tooth Root
Radiographic examination reveals a cystic lesion on the lateral aspect of the root of a normal tooth with a vital pulp.
Heart-Shaped Radiolucency in Maxillary Midline
Radiographic examination shows a heart-shaped, well-defined low-density area in the bone at the midline of the anterior maxilla.
Inverted Pear-Shaped Radiolucency Between Maxillary Teeth
Radiographic examination shows an inverted pear-shaped, well-defined low-density area in the bone between the maxillary lateral incisor and canine.
Midline Palatal Swelling with Radiolucency
The patient presents with a swelling at the midline of the hard palate, and radiographic examination reveals an intraosseous low-density area at that site.
Radiolucency Below Apices in Mandibular Midline
Radiographic examination shows a low-density area in the bone at the midline position, below the apices of the mandibular central incisors.
Doughy Midline Cyst in Floor of Mouth
A slow-growing cystic mass appears in the midline of the floor of the mouth, which is soft and pliable to the touch, like dough.
Pasty Cyst in Floor of Mouth or Faceneck Region
A cystic mass appears in the floor of the mouth or the faceneck region, containing keratin that is white, pasty, or cheese-like.
Cyst Anterior to Sternocleidomastoid Muscle
A well-defined cystic mass appears on the lateral side of the neck, at the anterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle.
Midline Neck Cyst Moves with Swallowing
A cystic mass appears on the midline of the neck, which moves up and down when the patient swallows or protrudes the tongue.
Joint Clicking or Locking
The temporomandibular joint produces a distinct clicking sound or gets stuck during opening or closing, preventing smooth movement.
Progressive Limitation of Mouth Opening
The patient's ability to open their mouth progressively worsens over time, potentially leading to a complete inability to open the mouth.
Masticatory Muscle Pain with Trigger Points
Aching or dull pain occurs in the facial masticatory muscles. Pressing on the muscles can locate one or more intensely painful spots that may also refer pain elsewhere.
Orofacial Pain
The patient feels pain or discomfort in the teeth, gums, jawbone, facial muscles, joints, etc.
Orofacial Swelling or Mass
There is visible swelling or a palpable abnormal mass inside the patient's mouth or on the face/neck.
Oral Dysfunction
The patient experiences difficulty or limitation in performing basic oral functions such as opening, closing, chewing, swallowing, or speaking.
Abnormal Tooth Condition
One or more teeth show sensitivity to cold, hot, sweet, or sour stimuli, loosening, color change, or loss of pulp vitality.
Radiographic Abnormality of the Jaw
Radiographic exams such as X-rays or CT scans show abnormal low-density, high-density, or mixed-density shadows in the jawbone area.
Abnormal Oral Secretion or Pus Discharge
There are abnormal secretions in the oral cavity, such as pus from the gums or mucosa, excessive salivation, or fluid with an unusual taste.
Malocclusion or Facial Asymmetry
The patient's upper and lower teeth do not fit together properly, or the facial appearance is asymmetrical.
TMJ Symptoms (Clicking/Pain/Locking)
The preauricular joint area experiences pain, clicking, crepitus, or gets stuck (locking) during movement.
Oral Mucosal Lesion
The oral mucosa (e.g., lips, cheeks, tongue, palate) shows ulcers, erosions, white or red patches, blisters, or abnormal coloration.
Gingival Abnormality
The gingival tissue bleeds during brushing or spontaneously, turns red, swells, or recedes towards the root of the tooth.
Facial Neurological Symptoms
The patient feels numbness, reduced sensation, tingling, or paroxysmal severe pain in the facial skin, lips, or tongue.
Relevant Orofacial History
The patient has a history of orofacial trauma, recurrent lesions, or habits such as lip biting or unilateral chewing.
